ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to deeply develop knowledge about the colonial Latin American World.
I learned to read, write, and talk in spanish at a more effective manner, especially in the context of literature.

One of my favorite language seminars I've taken at Yale! I'm coming away from this semester with a robust knowledge of colonial literature in Latin America, as well as an improved speaking ability. This course also improved my Spanish reading ability.
I learned a lot of Spanish vocabulary particular to colonization and religion.
I learned about literature written in 16th/17th century Spain and the surrounding context.

I definitely refined my Spanish speaking and writing skills. I really enjoyed being in a non-judgmental environment in which I, even as a non-native speaker, felt like I was encouraged to participate, even if I made a mistake.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: assignments and teacher 
Weaknesses: readings were sometimes spaced weird (70 page reading for two nights vs. 5 page reading for 5 nights) but this was uncommon.

Strengths: Professor Voigt is really great, she fosters an amazing environment where everyone can share their ideas and information. The class was structred pretty well where it was mostly discussion based. I think the one weakness was that later on it the class there were more big discussions that didn't give as many students opportunities to talk and engage as much as they wanted.

Strengths: Excellent instruction by both the professor and TF. From in-class discussions to feedback, Professor Voigt and Brais were wonderful resources and provided clear, helpful feedback on all assignments. I also appreciated the classroom environment they were able to foster -- by the end of the semester, we grew quite close as a class.

Weaknesses: No real weaknesses, except it was a bit unclear how we would use discussions on Canvas...I believe the idea was if you did not speak in class, you should post a comment on the discussion. However, this wasn't really enforced.

Strengths:
Engaging class discussions
Warm and kind-hearted professor and TF
Overall very welcoming for Spanish speakers of all backgrounds

Prof Voigt is very kind and doesnt make anyone feel dumb for making mistakes when speaking in class. because of this many people talk during our in class discussions which led to fruitful understandings of the material. The only weakness of the course is that sometimes the readings were a bit boring or too long or too difficult to read because colonial Spanish is much different from modern Spanish.
I really enjoyed this course! I liked that everyone had to pick a quote to share for everyone was engaged in the discussion. Also Seora Voigt and Brais are amazing!

The Professor and TF are a great combo. They assigned a good balance of independent readings, longer presentations/essays, and group work both in and out of class. Moreover, the course was interesting in its material and diversity of documents surrounding indigenous resistance and Spanish colonization. 

Group discussions were sometimes difficult to follow, just because we read documents in ancient Spanish and introduced jargon that was previously unfamiliar to me. I think this could be improved by incorporating a brief (1 paragraph or so) summary into each lecture slide, recapping the reading we had to do.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely! This is an extremely fun and fairly easy L5 course for spanish and it definitely helped me build my skills.

Yes! This is a great class for anyone pursuing L5 spanish, the certificate or even majoring, It's a fun class with great conversations. The profedsor is really engaging and really willing to help the students learn and do better.
Absolutely, especially if you're looking for an L5 credit. It may depend on who is teaching the course but the material is quite interesting.
Yes!!!!! Professor Voigt is such a delight to have as a professor and am upset that I can't take her class next semester!

yes, I would recommend this course especially for any student looking to get their Spanish certificate because professor Voigt is very kind. The workload isnt too heavy and the course is overall fun with a nice classroom environment.

I would! However, I will say I didn't expect so much historical literature (pretty much everything is autobiographical or biographical). At first I was disappointed but I grew to appreciate it as the semester progressed!
Yes for an enjoyable L5 credit! As long as you do the readings and actively engage in class, you should be totally fine.

extras.title: LAST 266 01/SPAN 266 01 - Studies In Latin American Lit
